text: Uber always has this mentality and Opendoor does too of like a twin turbine jet plane where you can fly the plane on one engine for a little bit if you need to, but it's operating most efficiently and effectively if both are working together.
speaker: Brian Tolkin
context: Lenny asks Brian about how product and operations teams should work together. Brian uses the metaphor of a 'twin turbine jet plane' to illustrate that both operations and product must function in harmony for optimal efficiency. He emphasizes that operations teams can provide valuable insights that inform product development, highlighting the importance of collaboration between the two functions.
text_ko: Uber와 Opendoor는 항상 쌍발 제트기처럼 생각해요. 한쪽 엔진만으로도 잠깐 비행할 수 있지만, 두 개의 엔진이 함께 작동할 때 가장 효율적이고 효과적으로 운영된다는 거죠.
text_zh: Uber 和 Opendoor 都有一种类似双涡轮喷气机的心态，虽然在需要时可以单独使用一台发动机飞行一段时间，但只有当两台发动机协同工作时，才能实现最高的效率和效果。
text_es: Uber siempre tiene esta mentalidad, al igual que Opendoor, de ser como un avión a reacción de doble turbina, donde puedes volar el avión con un motor por un tiempo si es necesario, pero está funcionando de manera más eficiente y efectiva cuando ambos trabajan juntos.
key_sentence: Uber and Opendoor operate most efficiently when both engines are working together.

text: Starting on the operations side gave a really deep understanding of how the business actually works. You are truly operating it day in and day out and the success of the city is in large part driven by the inputs that you are putting into it every single day on the ground.
speaker: Brian Tolkin
context: Lenny inquires about the impact of Brian's operations background on his product leadership. Brian explains that his experience in operations provided him with an intimate understanding of business dynamics, emphasizing that daily decisions and actions significantly influence success. He underscores the value of being close to the customer and understanding on-the-ground operations.
text_ko: 운영 쪽에서 시작하니까 비즈니스가 실제로 어떻게 돌아가는지 깊이 이해할 수 있었어요. 매일매일 직접 운영을 하니까, 도시의 성공이 여러분이 매일 현장에서 기여하는 부분에 크게 달려 있다는 걸 느끼게 돼요.
text_zh: 从运营方面入手，让我对业务的实际运作有了深入的理解。你每天都在实际操作中，城市的成功在很大程度上取决于你每天在现场投入的努力。
text_es: Comenzar en el área de operaciones me brindó una comprensión profunda de cómo funciona realmente el negocio. Estás operándolo día tras día y el éxito de la ciudad se debe en gran medida a las contribuciones que realizas cada día en el terreno.
key_sentence: Operations provide a deep understanding of inputs driving the city's success.

text: I think part of this may have been sharpened in the early days of Uber. Everything felt like a fire drill all the time. So the only way to operate, but I think you almost hit the nail on the head in the question, which is a little bit of an intellectual answer of when you reflect the stress onto your teams, everybody tenses up.
speaker: Brian Tolkin
context: Lenny discusses Brian's ability to stay calm under pressure. Brian reflects on his experience during the chaotic early days at Uber, noting that a stressful environment can negatively impact team performance. He shares that maintaining composure is crucial and that leaders should strive to prevent stress from affecting their teams, promoting a more productive atmosphere.
text_ko: 이건 아마 우버 초창기 때의 경험이 영향을 미쳤던 것 같아요. 항상 긴급 상황처럼 느껴졌거든요. 그래서 그렇게 운영할 수밖에 없었죠. 질문에서 거의 핵심을 찔렀다고 생각해요. 스트레스를 팀에 반영하게 되면, 모두가 긴장하게 되니까요.
text_zh: 我认为这部分可能源于Uber早期的日子。那时一切都像是在进行紧急演习。因此，唯一的运作方式就是这样，但我觉得你在提问时几乎抓住了关键，反思压力传递给团队时，大家都会变得紧张。
text_es: Creo que parte de esto puede haberse agudizado en los primeros días de Uber. Todo se sentía como una emergencia constante. Así que la única forma de operar era esa, pero creo que casi diste en el clavo con la pregunta, que es un poco una respuesta intelectual: cuando reflejas el estrés en tus equipos, todos se tensan.
key_sentence: Reflecting the stress onto teams causes everyone to tense up.

text: If you can really figure out this is really what matters, that's the core part of the job. It dovetails even back to our earlier conversation. In the early days of building tech and ops companies is where's the tech leverage? Same question, where's the kernel of what really matters that tech can uniquely solve?
speaker: Brian Tolkin
context: Lenny prompts Brian to elaborate on finding the essential elements in product development. Brian emphasizes that identifying what truly matters is critical for product managers, as it guides decision-making. He connects this idea to the importance of understanding where technology can provide leverage in business and product development.
text_ko: 이게 진짜 중요한 부분이라는 걸 제대로 파악할 수 있다면, 그게 바로 일의 핵심이에요. 아까 나눈 대화와도 연결되는 부분이죠. 기술과 운영 회사를 처음 만들 때는 기술의 레버리지(leverage)가 어디에 있는지 고민하게 되잖아요. 같은 질문이에요. 기술이 독특하게 해결할 수 있는 진짜 중요한 핵심이 어디에 있는지요.
text_zh: 如果你能真正弄清楚这才是最重要的，那就是这份工作的核心部分。这与我们之前的谈话是相辅相成的。在建立科技和运营公司初期，技术的杠杆在哪里？同样的问题，技术能够独特解决的真正关键是什么？
text_es: Si realmente puedes determinar qué es lo que realmente importa, esa es la parte central del trabajo. Esto se relaciona incluso con nuestra conversación anterior. En los primeros días de construir empresas de tecnología y operaciones, ¿dónde está la palanca tecnológica? La misma pregunta: ¿dónde está el núcleo de lo que realmente importa que la tecnología puede resolver de manera única?
key_sentence: Identifying tech leverage reveals the kernel of what really matters.

text: You have to be really good at pricing. You have to be really good at product, you have to be really good at the operations. You have to be really disciplined at risk. You have to be really good in the capital markets. And so you have to put all of these functions together to build a vertically integrated product.
speaker: Brian Tolkin
context: Lenny asks Brian about the challenges Zillow faced when entering the real estate market. Brian outlines the multifaceted nature of the business, explaining that success requires excellence across various domains, including pricing, product, operations, and risk management. He stresses the necessity of integrating these functions to create a successful product.
text_ko: 가격 책정에 정말 능숙해야 해요. 제품에 대해서도 잘 알아야 하고, 운영도 잘 해야 해요. 리스크 관리에 대해서도 정말 철저해야 하고요. 자본 시장에 대해서도 잘 알아야 해요. 그래서 이 모든 기능을 잘 조합해서 수직 통합된 제품을 만들어야 해요.
text_zh: 你必须在定价方面非常出色，产品方面也要非常优秀，运营管理同样要做到极致。同时，你还需要在风险控制上保持高度的纪律性，并且在资本市场上具备扎实的能力。因此，你需要将所有这些职能整合在一起，构建一个垂直整合的产品。
text_es: Debes ser realmente bueno en la fijación de precios. Debes ser excelente en el producto, en las operaciones y tener una gran disciplina en la gestión del riesgo. También necesitas ser competente en los mercados de capitales. Por lo tanto, es fundamental integrar todas estas funciones para construir un producto verticalmente integrado.
key_sentence: Building a vertically integrated product requires discipline in risk and capital markets.

text: The reality is vast, vast in our space. A vast majority of people still move the traditional way. And so this isn't something where it's like the size of the prize isn't particularly large enough short or anything like that.
speaker: Brian Tolkin
context: Lenny queries Brian about the competitive landscape following Zillow's entry into the market. Brian responds by emphasizing that the majority of real estate transactions still occur through traditional methods, indicating that there is ample opportunity for growth in the market. He reassures that staying focused on customer needs is more crucial than being overly concerned about competition.
text_ko: 현실은 정말 넓고, 우리 주변도 마찬가지예요. 대부분의 사람들은 여전히 전통적인 방식으로 움직이고 있어요. 그래서 이건 상금의 크기가 특별히 크지 않다는 그런 문제가 아니에요.
text_zh: 现实是广阔的，在我们的领域中更是如此。绝大多数人仍然以传统方式运作。因此，这并不是一个奖赏规模特别大的领域。
text_es: La realidad es amplia, muy amplia en nuestro sector. Una gran mayoría de las personas todavía se mueve de la manera tradicional. Por lo tanto, esto no es algo donde el tamaño de la recompensa (prize) sea particularmente grande en el corto plazo ni nada por el estilo.
key_sentence: A vast majority still move the traditional way; the size of the prize is limited.
